summary: This is a legal memorandum filed by Ghislaine Maxwell's defense team in support of a motion for individual sequestered juror voir dire and limited attorney-conducted voir dire. The document argues that intense negative pretrial publicity about Maxwell and Jeffrey Epstein, along with the sensitive nature of the charges, necessitates these special jury selection procedures to ensure a fair trial. This is a legal motion filed by Ghislaine Maxwell's defense team requesting individual sequestered voir dire and limited attorney-conducted questioning of prospective jurors. The motion argues that extensive pretrial publicity and the sensitive nature of the charges necessitate expanded voir dire procedures to ensure an impartial jury.

events.title: Filing of Defense Motion for Voir Dire
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell's defense team files a motion requesting individual sequestered voir dire and limited attorney-conducted questioning of prospective jurors.

locations: United States District Court Southern District of New York
keyFacts: Maxwell's defense argues that an 'unprecedented' and 'tsunami' of negative pretrial publicity has 'tried, convicted, and condemned' her in the court of public opinion, jeopardizing her right to a fair trial.
The defense cites extensive media coverage including millions of Google search results, numerous documentaries (Netflix, ABC), podcasts, and books specifically about Maxwell and Epstein.

The motion seeks individual sequestered voir dire to encourage honest juror responses on sensitive topics like sexual abuse and to avoid contaminating the jury pool with public discussions of pretrial publicity.
The defense also requests limited attorney-conducted voir dire, arguing that lawyers have more in-depth case knowledge to effectively probe for hidden juror biases.
The document links the media environment to other high-profile New York sex crime cases (Weinstein, R. Kelly, Cuomo) to argue the local jury pool is particularly saturated with related coverage.
The defense motion argues that extensive pretrial publicity related to Ghislaine Maxwell's case creates a high risk of juror prejudice, necessitating expanded voir dire procedures.
The motion requests individual sequestered voir dire and limited attorney-conducted questioning, citing legal precedents like United States v. Davis and United States v. Wood.
The defense proposes specific limitations on attorney-conducted voir dire, such as one minute per juror (expandable to three minutes if pursuing a cause challenge).
The document reveals that attorneys had been working on the case for well over a year by October 2021, indicating the complexity and duration of the legal proceedings.
